item.title: Portugal v Iceland: Euro 2016 – live!
item.description:
• Euro 2106 Group F updates from the 8pm BST kick-off in Saint-Etienne
  • Football, fire and ice: the inside story on the rise of Iceland
  • Interactive guide: every squad and player analysed
  • gregg.bakowski@theguardian.com on email or tweet @GreggBakowski

7.15pm BST

Away from tonight’s football, in Lille, where Russia play Slovakia tomorrow, there have been reports of minor scuffles between supporters there. Video footage shows some fans, believed to be Russia supporters, throwing a chair at a bar/restaurant where England and Wales fans had gathered together. Wales play England in nearby Lens on Thursday.

7.09pm BST

Team news Portugal v Iceland: pic.twitter.com/k8TxtGVQ23

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Gregg Bakowski

item.title: Russia handed suspended Euro 2016 disqualification and lash out at England
item.description:
• Further unrest could see side thrown out; coach slams ‘unethical’ England fans
• Russia’s striker Artem Dzyuba: ‘In every conflict there are two parts’

Russia will be disqualified from Euro 2016 if there is a repeat of the crowd trouble seen at the Stade Vélodrome that marred their opening match with England in Marseille, Uefa has ruled. However the Russian striker Artem Dzyuba immediately responded that the English fans were no angels and equally to blame.

Related: Euro 2016: French police start process of deporting Russians over fan violence

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Owen Gibson in Lille

item.title: Athletes ‘have lost faith’ in doping chiefs over Russia failures
item.description:
• ‘Our confidence has been shattered,’ says letter to IOC and Wada presidents
• IAAF to decide on Friday if Russian athletes are allowed to compete in Rio

The International Olympic Committee and the World Anti-Doping Agency stand accused of “shattering the confidence” of athletes across the globe because of their failure to do enough to tackle Russian doping in a powerful private letter seen by the Guardian.

The letter sent directly to the IOC’s president, Thomas Bach, and his Wada counterpart, Sir Craig Reedie, also warns both men that their “tried and tested procedures and safeguards have been proved inadequate” and urges them to do more to “fully discover the truth” about cheating in sport. It comes as the International Association of Athletics Federations, the sport’s governing body, meets in Vienna on Friday to decide whether Russian athletes should be allowed to compete in the Rio Olympic Games in August.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Exclusive by Sean Ingle

item.title: Hungary’s Adam Szalai finds scoring touch to defeat 10-man Austria
item.description:
Adam Szalai is not exactly prolific. Hungary’s No9 managed to go through the whole of last season without scoring for both the clubs he represented – Hoffeneim and Hannover – and he came into this tournament without a goal for his country since October 2014. This was the day, though, when everything changed for the man who paid for a round of Palinka for 200 people in Budapest after Hungary qualified for Euro 2016.

A wayward free header in the first half, which ended up looking more like a clearance than an attempt on goal, betrayed a glaring lack of confidence and Szalai waved an apologetic head in the air early in the second half after making a pig’s ear of another opportunity. Yet everything fell into place for the striker in the 62nd minute when he nicked the ball past Robert Almer and ran into the arms of the Hungary supporters behind the goal to cherish a feeling that was long overdue.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Stuart James at the Stade de Bordeaux

item.title: Chris Gayle: ‘You’re with men. You’re good-looking. What do you expect?’
item.description:
The West Indies star is used to defending himself but insists the sexism row over his interview with an Australian TV reporter was blown out of proportion

Chris Gayle doesn’t trust me but blunt honesty is preferable when, in exchange, he is fiercely concentrated during our hour together. The West Indies batsman is calm yet defiant, combative but wounded. Before we offer our contrasting opinions, when it feels right to tell Gayle his attitude towards women is wrong and for him to voice suspicion of “you people”, he warrants serious attention.

Earlier this year, before the World T20, the English cricket pundit Mark Nicholas dismissed Gayle and his team-mates. In a breathtakingly arrogant and nonsensical phrase, Nicholas wrote: “The West Indies are short of brains.”

Continue reading...

media:content.media:credit: Photograph: Linda Nylind for the Guardian
Photograph: Linda Nylind for the Guardian

item.dc:creator: Donald McRae

item.title: Huddersfield youngster Ronan Costello dies after incident in under-19s game
item.description:
• Player had been on life support after incident in match against Salford
• Coach Chris Thorman: ‘Rest in peace. You were a pleasure to be around’

A promising Huddersfield Giants rugby player has died at the age of 17 after being seriously injured in an under-19s match.

Ronan Costello was airlifted to Leeds General Infirmary after the incident during the game against Salford on Saturday.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Josh Halliday and Aaron Bower

item.title: England’s Joe Marler faces RFU sanction for tweet about former Australia coach
item.description:
• Marler used Twitter to criticise Bob Dwyer with abusive epithet
• Dwyer accused Dan Cole of illegal scrummaging in England’s Brisbane win

The England prop Joe Marler has risked sanction from the Rugby Football Union after using social media to direct an obscene remark at the former Australia coach Bob Dwyer.

Marler used Twitter to call Dwyer a wanker in response to his claim that Dan Cole scrummaged illegally in the first Test against the Wallabies. The tweet was quickly deleted but the RFU has strict guidelines on the use of social media and Marler, a member of England’s elite player squad, now faces a reprimand.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Press Association

item.title: Galileo Gold wins St James’s Palace under brilliant Frankie Dettori
item.description:
• Jockey jubilant after victory on the opening day of Royal Ascot
• Favourite The Gurkha finishes late and fast for second place

Frankie Dettori seized control of the St James’s Palace Stakes here on Tuesday in the first few strides, and he did not let go until Galileo Gold was safely past the post. Ideally placed at every stage, Dettori used the winner’s speed and stride to maximum effect, and could then choose his moment to strike for home and claim the Royal meeting’s battle of the Guineas winners.

As he did so, Galileo Gold reversed his form with Awtaad in last month’s Irish 2,000 Guineas, and denied a substantial gamble on The Gurkha, who took the French equivalent. Ryan Moore, The Gurkha’s jockey, is rightly seen by many as the best rider in the business, but here he was frustrated by the undisputed master of Ascot, as Dettori covered the round mile with merciless efficiency.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Greg Wood at Ascot

item.title: Operation Puerto blood bags must be released to authorities, judge orders
item.description:
• Madrid court finds Wada and the UCI should be given access
• Ruling follows successful appeal against decision to destroy bags

One of the sport’s biggest doping scandals is in the spotlight again with the release to authorities of 211 bags of frozen blood belonging to leading athletes from cycling, athletics, football and other sports.

An appeal court in Madrid ruled on Tuesday that the 211 blood bags found in the fridge and freezer of Eufemiano Fuentes, the Spanish medic known as “Doctor Blood”, should be handed over to laboratories in Spain, Italy and elsewhere.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Giles Tremlett in Madrid

item.title: Maria Sharapova appeals against 'unfairly harsh' two-year drugs ban
item.description:
• Five-time grand slam winner star appeals to CAS, sport’s highest court
  • Sharapova banned for two years for positive meldonium test

Maria Sharapova has lodged an appeal against her two-year doping ban – and wants a swift resolution to the legal process, with a view to competing at the Olympics in August.

Related: What is meldonium and why did Maria Sharapova take it?

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian sport

item.title: Royal Ascot 2016: horse-by-horse guide to Prince of Wales’s Stakes
item.description:
A Shin Hikari is the hot favourite as six horses line up for the feature event of the Flat season’s centrepiece meeting on Wednesday

Japanese raider is a prolific winner, including in £1.1m Hong Kong Cup in December. Produced an astonishing performance on European debut last month to win Group One at Chantilly by an official margin of 10 lengths (looked more like seven) from a horse that had won a Group One three weeks earlier. That was on heavy going, suggesting he is versatile as to ground, since his home wins were on a very fast surface. Deservedly the hot favourite in this small field, though a second such performance cannot be taken for granted after travelling around the world.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Chris Cook

item.title: Why Kyrie Irving is more important than LeBron in the NBA finals' buddy movie
item.description:
Cleveland’s title hopes have a glimmer of life after victory in Game 5. But with LeBron James’s excellence a given, an extra burden falls on the team’s other standout

Twelve months ago, LeBron James lost in the NBA finals to the Golden State Warriors – despite putting up one of the most dominating performances in the history of the playoffs. Even LeBron’s historic talents were not enough to overcome a deeper opponent 1-on-5 and the finals ended in six games.

Through the first four games of this year’s finals, it looked like more of the same. LeBron was mostly still his excellent self, but the Warriors remained the better overall team, and Cleveland’s unbalanced approach left them trailing 3-1 and facing elimination in Oakland on Monday night. But no confetti fell after Game 5, and the full-on debate about the 2015-16 Warriors place in basketball history was tabled. The series unexpectedly moves to a Game 6, and the Cavaliers head back to Cleveland after a 112-97 win with hope. Maybe even momentum. At the very least, they’re alive.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: DJ Gallo

item.title: Gareth Bale says no England players would get into Wales team
item.description:
• Wales forward stokes up rivalry before long-awaited Euro 2016 showdown
• ‘I didn’t say they didn’t have pride or passion. In my opinion we have more’

Gareth Bale has continued his bullishness towards England by stating none of Roy Hodgson’s players are good enough to be in the Wales team.

Related: Wales’ Chris Coleman confident Gareth Bale will back up big talk against England

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Jamie Jackson in Dinard

item.title: Usain Bolt to race in 200m at next month’s London Anniversary Games
item.description:
• Bolt competing as part of preparations for Rio Olympics
• Jamaican will up against Great Britain’s Adam Gemili

Usain Bolt will fine-tune his preparations for the Rio Olympics by competing at the Anniversary Games in London on 22 July.

Organisers of the event, staged at the stadium where Bolt won double sprint gold and the 4x100m relay in 2012, said the Jamaican world record holder would race in the 200m.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: Chiefs ruin Warren Gatland’s Hamilton homecoming with Wales
item.description:
• Chiefs 40-7 Wales

There was no happy homecoming for Warren Gatland in Hamilton as Chiefs, the Waikato Super Rugby side, defeated his Wales side 40-7. The game was supposed to be a “thank you” from the Welsh to the people of his hometown for the support they showed them at the 2011 World Cup, but the home side ran in six tries in a comfortable outing for them.

Gatland was looking for players to put up their hands for selection for Saturday’s second Test in Wellington, particularly as he needs to replace the wing George North because of a hamstring injury, but he saw little to commend any of them.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Press Association

item.title: England close on Pakistan in ICC rankings as four-Test series approaches
item.description:
• Alastair Cook’s side lie fourth, three ranking points behind summer tourists
• Jonny Bairstow 167 helps him enters world’s top 20 batsman list for first time

England’s Test series victory over Sri Lanka has put them within striking distance of their next opponents Pakistan in the International Cricket Council rankings.

Related: Five talking points from Lord’s: England win Sri Lanka Test series | Vic Marks

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Press Association

item.title: NHL picks Las Vegas as expansion franchise, reports say
item.description:
• AP says Las Vegas has beaten out Quebec City for 2017-18 team
  • NHL commissioner Gary Bettman proposes fee of $500m

The NHL is reportedly heading to Las Vegas – providing officials can come up with $500m to secure a new franchise.

Related: This year's Stanley Cup playoffs had it all. If only hockey fans had watched it

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian sport and agencies

item.title: Heineken’s F1 deal leads to further call for ban on alcohol sponsorship
item.description:
• Eurocare wants stronger legislation from the EC and member states
• Heineken’s deal worth $150m to F1 over five years

Heineken’s new sponsorship deal with Formula One has led to renewed calls from European campaigners for a ban on alcohol sponsorship in the sport.

Eurocare, which groups together public-health and non-governmental organisations, said on Tuesday that it wants stronger legislation from the European Commission (EC) and member states. France, a country without a Formula One grand prix, already bans alcohol sponsorship of sporting events.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: Republic of Ireland fans sing tribute for Northern Ireland fan who died in Nice
item.description:
Fans sang ‘Stand up for the Ulsterman’ during their match against Sweden in memory to Darren Rodgers, who died in Nice while following Northern Ireland

With fan trouble dominating the headlines, both Republic of Ireland and Sweden supporters were in fantastic voice before, during and after their game at the Stade de France on Monday. The Republic of Ireland supporters paid tribute to Northern Ireland fan Darren Rodgers, who died in Nice at the weekend after a fall. In the 24th minute of the game fans sang “Stand up for the Ulstermen” in his memory.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Tom Stevens

item.title: Eddie Jones: Craig Joubert will referee Australia v England not pundit Kearns
item.description:
• England coach hits back at former Wallaby’s illegal scrummaging comments
• ‘Phil is part of an organised campaign and he is playing his role’

Actions are supposed to speak louder than words but not when an English rugby team are touring Australia. For the second successive day Eddie Jones has felt the need to have a dig at a former Wallaby, this time for claiming England are cheating in the scrums. He has already received an apology from a former international who asked him a tasteless question following Saturday’s win in the first Test in Brisbane.

Related: England’s Eddie Jones questions extent of injury to Australia’s David Pocock

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Robert Kitson in Melbourne

item.title: Sepp Blatter: European competition draw was rigged by cooling balls
item.description:
• Former Fifa president says he saw cheating taking place
  • Blatter adds he never saw draw fixing on his watch at Fifa

Sepp Blatter, the disgraced former Fifa president, has claimed he witnessed the fixing of a draw for a European football competition.

Blatter, in an interview with Argentinian newspaper La Nacion, did not elaborate on which competition he believed was rigged, but said he had seen a practice whereby the balls containing team names were cooled to make their identification possible when being picked out.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian sport

item.title: Jon Walters in doubt after limping out of Republic of Ireland’s opener
item.description:
• Stoke forward admits achilles problem flared up early in Sweden match
• ‘I was trying to run and jump to see if it settled down – it didn’t’

Jon Walters faces an anxious wait to find out if his participation in Euro 2016 is over after he limped out of the Republic of Ireland’s opener with Sweden.

Related: Republic of Ireland give up draw to Sweden with Ciaran Clark own goal

Continue reading...

media:content.media:credit: Photograph: David Maher/Sportsfile via Getty Images
Photograph: David Maher/Sportsfile via Getty Images

item.dc:creator: Chris Cook

item.title: Royal Ascot meeting will start on the softest ground since 1971
item.description:
• More rain overnight has made conditions even more testing
• Speculation grows that royal procession may be called off

Royal Ascot will begin on Tuesday on ground described officially as soft for the first time since 1971. The famous turf has taken a soaking in recent days and a further 4mm of rain overnight prompted the latest change in the going description and several non-runners, whose numbers will swell as the week continues.

Related: The Gurkha can win St James’s Palace at Royal Ascot for Aidan O’Brien

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Chris Cook at Ascot

item.title: Off-colour Australia fall to West Indies in Caribbean ODI tri-series
item.description:
• Australia 265-7; West Indies 266-6 (45.4 overs)
  • West Indies win by four wickets with 26 balls remaining

Australia paid the price for a sub-par total, ineffectual bowling and early dropped catches in St Kitts, where West Indies recorded a four-wicket win in the ODI tri-series clash.

Usman Khawaja (98) and Steve Smith (74), both promoted one spot up the order because of David Warner’s broken finger, took control of the game in a 170-run stand. The hosts did well to restrict Australia to 265-7 then Marlon Samuels top-scored with 92 as his side hauled in the target with 4.2 overs remaining.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Australian Associated Press

item.title: James and Irving sizzle as Cavaliers beat Warriors to keep NBA finals alive
item.description:
• Cleveland take Game 5 in Oakland to leave series at 3-2
  • Kyrie Irving and LeBron James both score 41 points

Missing Draymond Green thanks to a one-game suspension, the Golden State Warriors were denied – for now, at least – their second NBA championship in as many years, as the Cleveland Cavaliers snapped back from the brink of elimination to force a Game 6 with a 112-97 victory on Monday night.

A fiery, raucous crowd at Oracle Arena witnessed a substandard shooting performance from the home team and a lights-out night from the Cavs tandem of Kyrie Irving and LeBron James. The loss of Green to suspension cleared the paint for dribble penetration from Irving and when he sat back to take a mid-range jumper, he looked as though he could not miss. Both James and Irving finished with 41 points. James also added seven assists, three steals, and three blocks to his stat line. All Warrior fans could muster was a “Free Draymond” chant or two (and some more unsavory chants directed at King James that included a word that starts with a B and ends with an Itch) as the clock wound down.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Dave Schilling at Oracle Arena

item.title: Jordan Spieth confident of US Open defence despite Masters collapse
item.description:
• World No2 says being defending champion will help ‘if I get into contention’
• Spieth adds that he is looking forward to competing at the Rio Olympics

Jordan Spieth insists he will not be troubled by thoughts of what happened to him at the Masters two months ago when he looks to defend his US Open title this week at Oakmont Country Club in Pennsylvania.

The 22-year-old American lost the chance to claim back-to-back green jackets when he suffered a dramatic final-round collapse while leading at Augusta National in April, with England’s Danny Willett taking advantage to win his first major.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Press Association

item.description:
Profiles of all 24 teams and 552 players at Euro 2016, including caps, goals, hobbies, tattoos, music taste and ratings for every individual performance

item.description:
Fixtures, groups, venues and more – all you need to know about the European Championships with our handy interactive wallchart

item.title: David Squires on … Euro 2016 quite literally kicking off
item.description:
Chairs, flares and Jogi Löw – please don’t go down there: it’s the opening weekend at Euro 2016. And you can find David’s archive of cartoons here

  • David Squires on the big Euro 2016 kick-off in France
  • David Squires on … this year’s Copa América in the US

item.dc:creator: David Squires

item.title: Euro 2016: Xherdan Shaqiri drops a bombshell as Swiss prepare for Romania | David Hytner
item.description:
Stoke City forward has disturbed the calm at Switzerland’s camp by claiming he may declare for Kosovo after being overlooked as captain

Everything was calm at the Switzerland training base in Montpellier. The team could draw confidence from the 1-0 win over Albania in their opening Euro 2016 Group A tie and, with a tough test looming against Romania in Paris on Wednesday evening, there was a cautious optimism that at the fourth time of asking they could finally advance into the knockout stages of this competition.

Then Xherdan Shaqiri dropped what can only be described as a bombshell. “What if the coach of Kosovo wants me as the captain? Of course, I am thinking about it then,” the Switzerland winger said.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: David Hytner in Paris

item.title: Just give the ball to Cristiano Ronaldo – Portugal’s Plan A (and B) | Barney Ronay
item.description:
The world’s highest-paid athlete is about to start his fourth European Championship and, after scoring 32 goals for his country since the last one, he really is a superstar with nothing left to prove

Should Portugal end up leaving these Euros in disappointment, as they did the last World Cup, Cristiano Ronaldo can at least console himself with the idea of donning his favourite mildewed Withnail & I greatcoat, sinking a few bottles of Margaux ’53 and announcing, as per Richard E Grant’s famous turn in a genteel Penrith tea shop, that he is going to come back in here and buy this place.

Win the Euros? Ronaldo can afford to stage his own if he really feels like it. This may not be the best use of his reported $310m fortune but there is still an amusing symmetry in the fact Euro 2016’s record €301m prize money tab could, in event of some lost-wallet Uefa emergency, be covered by the world’s highest-paid athlete.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Barney Ronay in Paris

item.title: Wes Hoolahan says Republic of Ireland good enough to reach last 16
item.description:
Midfielder scored goal against Sweden and thinks a repeat of that performance will see them reach Euro 2016 knockout stages

Wes Hoolahan called it the goal of his life and on every level, it was perfect – down to the detail of his family being on the right side of the Stade de France, which allowed him to celebrate in front of them.

The Republic of Ireland midfielder’s beautifully executed half-volley against Sweden on Monday made him only the fourth player to score for his country at a European Championship finals. More importantly, it put the team 1-0 up in the 48th minute and was just reward for their dominance of the game.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: David Hytner in Paris

item.title: Nick Compton has some cause for pride as he heads for England Test exit door | The Spin
item.description:
The Middlesex batsman’s Test career looks set to end in failure but then so do most such careers and Nick Compton has cause for pride over his 16 matches

Looks like the end, then, for Nick Compton. The final acts of his short England career being the few pieces of fielding he did in between all the squalls and showers on the fifth day of the third Test. His last innings was late on Saturday afternoon. Promoted to open in Alastair Cook’s absence, he made 19. Another disappointing knock but one which at least included three fine shots – a cut, a clip, and a drive. As the sage Scyld Berry wrote in the Telegraph the next day, there are worse ways to go than by middling a few sweet strokes for four on a sunny Saturday at Lord’s, before being applauded off by a sympathetic crowd. You hope Compton, when he looks back, will be able to appreciate that.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Andy Bull

item.title: Ronald Koeman should beware at Everton – Goodison grass is not always greener | Jacob Steinberg
item.description:
The Dutchman is moving to a bigger club with a large fanbase and vast potential but he may soon realise a big budget brings added pressure as well as possibilities

The pessimistic view when Ronald Koeman moved to Southampton in 2014 was that he had accepted a hospital pass, bearing in mind they were struggling to absorb an intense and bruising talent drain on and off the pitch. In reality it was more like a ball from Xavi.

It is understandable that the mood at Everton is celebratory after days of protracted negotiations ended with them securing Koeman as Roberto Martínez’s replacement. After Martínez allowed his commitment to possession football to spill over into a dogmatism, a blind spot towards defending that eventually proved to be the Spaniard’s undoing, now they have a manager who has demonstrated an ability to strike the right balance between defence and attack during his impressive spell at Southampton.

Continue reading...

media:content.media:credit: Photograph: Tony McArdle - Everton FC/Everton FC via Getty Images
Photograph: Tony McArdle - Everton FC/Everton FC via Getty Images

item.dc:creator: Jacob Steinberg

item.title: Five talking points from Lord’s: England win Sri Lanka Test series | Vic Marks
item.description:
Sri Lanka improved with each Test in tricky conditions, there was progress with England’s openers but the middle order and wicketkeeping dilemmas remain

Sri Lanka are not in freefall. From a low base they improved with every Test in alien conditions. They fought hard at Lord’s with the series already lost. A pragmatic pace attack led by Nuwan Pradeep kept plugging away. Young batsmen learnt rapidly; Kaushal Silva, Kusal Mendis and the not so young Dimuth Karunaratne (28) were still relishing the challenge of facing Jimmy Anderson and Stuart Broad. Meanwhile the veteran Rangana Herath was mildly inspirational – at least to the legions of middle-aged cricketers out there. Their defeat does not suggest terminal decline but a lull while they try to rebuild after the retirements of their recent great players.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Vic Marks at Lord's

item.title: Lille braces itself for Euro 2016 invasion of British supporters
item.description:
Northern French will welcome fans from England, Wales – and Russia – this week and the mood is one of calm rather than preparing for a Euro 2016 storm

Early afternoon in the cobbled Place du Général de Gaulle, the summer drizzle sending the bar staff scurrying out to collect chairs, and Les Lillois are counting the cost of life as a host city at the European Championship. Fans from Germany and Ukraine had clashed briefly in the square the previous day before their teams’ meeting at Stade Pierre Mauroy. Those scenes had been far removed from the running street battles of Marseille, but the Russians are here this week and those English not destined for nearby Lens will also be in town.

Related: Six England fans jailed in connection with Marseille violence at Euro 2016

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Dominic Fifield in Lille

item.title: Chan Yuen-ting: the female coach who took a men's team to a national title
item.description:
She took Eastern to the Hong Kong Premier league title at the age of just 27. And now she has her eyes on a job in Europe

Forget the East Midlands, perhaps the biggest story of the football year is in east Asia, where Eastern won the Hong Kong Premier League title in April. The wait since the last championship had been 21 years but the headlines were all about the 27 year-old head coach Chan Yuen-ting.

Just days after lifting the trophy, she was presented with another prize. This time it came from the Guinness Book of World Records, for being the first woman to win a top-flight title in men’s professional football.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: John Duerden

item.title: Andy Murray and Ivan Lendl on mission to down Novak Djokovic
item.description:
Andy Murray knows he needs help from someone special to get past the player who holds all four grand slam titles – and reuniting with Ivan Lendl fits the bill

Almost from the day Andy Murray properly stepped into the public gaze for the first time, at Wimbledon 11 years ago, the analysis of his mental and physical fortitude has been intense, unrelenting and, sometimes, wholly justified.

Murray became a laboratory experiment, a hamster on a wheel to be poked and examined for strengths and weaknesses under pressure, as the nation waited for him to deliver. It is not what he had ever hoped for; all he has ever wanted to do is hit a tennis ball as well as he can.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Kevin Mitchell at Queen's

item.title: How to cope without David Pocock in the Wallabies' second Test against England? | Matt Cleary
item.description:
Combatting Eddie Jones’ buoyant England side without the influential Pocock will be a challenge for the Wallabies; the answer may lie in organised chaos

David Pocock is like a big lump of lead. He could stand the middle of a yacht in the Sydney to Hobart race and defy the raging tempest of a storm in Bass Strait. The man is ballast. It’s like he’s heavier than normal people. And over the ball, hoovering it up, all balance, body-height and impossible arms, you’d sooner shift a piano up the stairs. And the Wallabies would accept no substitute.

Unless they have to because he’s injured, of course, in which case they could bung in the tearaway Sean McMahon. Or they could replace Pocock at No8 with Ben McCalman or Wycliff Palu, two big bodies who’ve been around. There’s even the dextrous and nimble openside “fetcher”, Queensland’s Liam Gill.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Matt Cleary

item.title: Five things we learned from Lewis Hamilton’s Canadian Grand Prix success
item.description:
Max Verstappen has put Monaco behind him, Hamilton’s relationship with Nico Rosberg has not improved but he is on good terms with Sebastian Vettel

Monaco could not have been much worse for Max Verstappen, he finished in the wall three times in Monte Carlo, the third, in the race, ending his afternoon. Worse still that final crash was virtually identical to his first, suggesting he was failing to learn from his mistakes. It had been a sobering weekend after the elation of a debut F1 win in the previous round in Spain, and in Montreal the Mercedes’ executive director, Toto Wolff, stirred things further. “Max Verstappen acts more like a teenager. In the car he’s extremely good but, when you interact with him, he’s a kid,” he said. Already doubtless banned from a night on the cider, hanging around outside the chippy trying to impress girls with the moves on his BMX after Monaco, this will have stung. His reaction was a drive of exceptional maturity to hold off the charging Nico Rosberg at the Circuit Gilles Villeneuve. Verstappen defended fourth from Rosberg for several laps toward the end of the race with all the skill of a seasoned pro and was so successful that eventually a frustrated Rosberg was forced into a spin. “Monaco was a tough weekend for him,” said Red Bull’s team principal, Christian Horner. “But the way he has bounced back here, the confidence he has had, throwing the car around, was great. It was a pretty mature drive for somebody that Mr Wolff said was not quite as mature as he thought. He looked pretty mature to me when he was fending off his very experienced driver.”

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Giles Richards

item.title: Zlatan Ibrahimovic locates magic touch to make inevitable mark for Sweden
item.description:
Sweden’s talisman looked set to leave frustrated by Republic of Ireland but he never hid and eventually created his team’s equaliser

is As Zlatan Ibrahimovic surveyed the rousing scene before kick-off, he gave a little nod as if to deign this arena and occasion worthy of his presence. The man who famously said a World Cup without him was not worth watching was ready. We could begin.

It is unlikely he expected to trudge off at half-time having been shackled by a combination of robust Irish defending, that pushed him ever deeper, and error-strewn, haphazard Swedish link-up play.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Owen Gibson at Stade de France

item.title: Spain’s emergency striker highlights Del Bosque’s goals concern | Sid Lowe
item.description:
Once again Spain dominated possession, completing more than three times as many passes as the Czechs, and once again the goal did not come, until Gerard Piqué was thrown up front as a last-ditch measure

Gerard Piqué once joked that the solution to those games when there was no way through, when teams defended deep against Spain or Barcelona, frustrating them, when the clock kept running and the chances kept coming but the ball just wouldn’t go in, was simple: stick him up front sooner. Spain had tried it all here, opportunities and players arriving one after the other after the other, but still Petr Cech would not be beaten. Until the 87th minute when, at last, it happened; when, at last, there he was.

Related: Spain’s Gerard Piqué leaves it late to break Czech Republic resistance

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Sid Lowe at the Stadium de Toulouse

item.title: NSW Blues' loyalty policy threatens to continue losing trend in State of Origin | Nick Tedeschi
item.description:
The Blues go to Suncorp with a mountain to climb after selectors went with the same conservative, defence-first blueprint that has failed time and time again

The overused and often trite definition of insanity is doing the same thing over and over again and expecting different results.

In the New South Wales camp, despite staring down the gullet of the Blues’ 10th loss in 11 years, selectors Laurie Daley and Bob Fulton continue to push blind loyalty above all when it comes to team selection.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Nick Tedeschi

item.title: Nick Dougherty: my best day in golf was playing with Tiger Woods at US Open
item.description:
The Englishman will be analysing for television rather than competing at Oakmont this week but remembers the third round at the same venue in 2007 as ‘playing with a bit of history and better than any of the wins’

Nick Dougherty is at least spared the question of “Whatever happened to?” His prominence as an excellent television analyst means he remains part of golf’s consciousness.

Related: Oakmont test can provide Spieth with a major reason to forget his travails | Ewan Murray

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Ewan Murray

item.title: Royal Ascot 2016: horse-by-horse guide to St James’s Palace Stakes
item.description:
The Gurkha is the favourite as eight horses line up for the feature event of the Flat season’s centrepiece meeting on Tuesday

Only defeat came on debut in October, since when he has improved for each race and won Irish 2,000 Guineas last time, by two and a half lengths from Galileo Gold. Benefited from run of the race that day, getting a clear run while his rival met trouble, but travelled smoothly and may well have won in any case. Ground was very testing that day and risk he could be found out on a faster surface but recent rain will ensure there is some give underfoot this time.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Chris Cook

item.title: Justin Leppitsch's shaky AFL coaching tenure shows the importance of belief | Mick Ellis
item.description:
As the Brisbane coach faces calls for his sacking we’re reminded again that like religious prophets, football coaches require an audience of true believers

Like his embattled coach, Brisbane Lions captain Tom Rockliff has been increasingly busy on the ramparts. It’s the lot of a senior player when a team is failing. After one win in 12 rounds, the Lions are warding off the disbelievers.

Yes, Brisbane still had faith in coach Justin Leppitsch and his methods, Rockliff was telling RSN radio on Friday. “If there was no pressure from the outside on Leppa you would be surprised, but within the four walls the boys have faith in the system and the way we play.”

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Mick Ellis

item.title: How a good story can count as much as stats in the dugout
item.description:
When two sabermetricians took charge of Sonoma Stompers they soon found advanced analytics were useless without a genuine feel for locker-room politics

Back when newspaper pockets were swollen enough to send numerous hacks into the lower leagues every Saturday I ended up covering Tony Pulis’s first game as Stoke City manager in November 2002. It did not start well. After 70 minutes his new team were 3-0 behind to Walsall and Pulis was staring glumly at the sodden turf. That at least had one benefit: it meant he could not see the Stoke fans angrily heckling him. But he sure as hellcould hear them. “You don’t know what you are doing,” they spat, each chant more venomous than the last.

You hear it all the time. The sound of fans thinking they know best. But rarely is a manager able to stick two metaphorical fingers back as quickly as Pulis did that day. While the chants were still ringing out he brought on Andy Cooke and Chris Greenacre and switched to three up front. Within minutes both substitutes had scored and Stoke came close to an unlikely point. Maybe, as I wrote at the time, Pulis knew what he was doing after all.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Sean Ingle

item.title: This year's Stanley Cup playoffs had it all. If only hockey fans had watched it
item.description:
The anemic television ratings for this year’s compelling NHL post-season raise an important question: why don’t hockey fans like hockey?

The 2016 NHL playoffs are over, and perhaps not a moment too soon for broadcasters. We will wait to see how ratings for Game 6 – the season’s finale – which featured the Pittsburgh Penguins claiming their fourth Stanley Cup, seven years to the day since they won their last one, in 2009. Yet, chances are the numbers are not good. And it might seem besides the point to bring this up now, but perhaps we might waver on these stats, rather than those from ice level, for a little while, because it’s through them we might start asking more interesting questions.

For instance: why don’t hockey fans like hockey?

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Colin Horgan

item.title: Félix Verdejo's solid win continues tradition of impressive boxing pedigree
item.description:
The blue-chip prospect from San Juan stayed on course for the stardom he’s been preordained for with a fifth-round TKO of Mexico’s Juan José Martinez

The fistic pedigree of Puerto Rico is almost unthinkably robust for an island smaller than Connecticut in both size and population. The US territory has produced heaps of world champions since boxing was legalized there in 1927, among them Carlos Ortíz, Edwin Rosario, Esteban DeJesús, Wilfred Benítez, Wilfredo Gómez, Félix Trinidad and dozens more.

The most recent exponent of that proud tradition was Miguel Cotto, who two years ago became the only Puerto Rican fighter to capture world titles in four weight classes when he retired Sergio Martínez at Madison Square Garden to win the lineal middleweight championship. That marked Cotto’s ninth appearance at the hallowed Manhattan arena where he routinely headlined during the weekend of the Puerto Rican Day parade, selling more than 150,000 combined tickets.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Bryan Armen Graham

item.title: Ronald Koeman confirmed as Everton manager after leaving Southampton
item.description:
• Dutchman joins Goodison club on a £6m-a-year deal
• Koeman guided Saints to sixth in Premier League last season

Everton have confirmed the appointment of Ronald Koeman as their manager, with the Dutch coach signing a three-year deal to succeed Roberto Martínez at Goodison Park.

Related: Ronald Koeman should beware at Everton – Goodison grass is not always greener | Jacob Steinberg

Continue reading...

media:content.media:credit: Photograph: Tony McArdle - Everton FC/Everton FC via Getty Images
Photograph: Tony McArdle - Everton FC/Everton FC via Getty Images

item.dc:creator: Andy Hunter

item.title: Euro 2016: Russia rolls back support of violence as deportation process begins
item.description:
• Russian authorities retreat on perceived official support of scenes in Marseille
• Far-right activist Alexander Shprygin among ‘fans’ stopped by French police

On Tuesday, there was something of a rollback of Russian official support for the fan violence that has dogged the early days of Euro 2016. A day previously, the MP Igor Lebedev, who sits on the executive board of the Russian football union, said he saw nothing wrong with the scenes: “Quite the opposite lads, keep it up!” The top law enforcement official Vladimir Markin said the fans were “real men” and Europe had become too used to gay parades to recognise them as such.

Related: Russia handed suspended Euro 2016 disqualification and fined €150,000

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Shaun Walker in Moscow

item.title: Spain’s signature style creates an old problem for their new faces | Sid Lowe
item.description:
Aritz Aduriz and Álvaro Morata made their tournament debuts in the 1-0 win over Czech Republic and must get used to opponents making their lives difficult

“It’s not easy to beat a team that builds a wall,” Nolito said. In his first competition game for Spain the Celta Vigo forward had experienced something that has long since become familiar for his new international team-mates. Spain did eventually find a way round the Czech wall, as they have eventually overcome many of the barriers erected before them, but not until the 87th minute when the central defender Gerard Piqué headed in the winner.

Aritz Aduriz and Álvaro Morata were making their tournament debuts, too; they follow on from a long line of strikers Spain have tried and largely left behind. It is not that Roberto Soldado, Álvaro Negredo, Fernando Llorente, Michu, Diego Costa and Paco Alcácer are bad, it is that the striking role for Spain is more specific and difficult than it appears, as Morata and Aduriz saw in Toulouse. As Aduriz departed the municipal stadium, apple in hand, the question was direct: why is it so hard to score goals?

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Sid Lowe in Toulouse

item.title: Sofiane Feghouli signs for West Ham from Valencia on free transfer
item.description:
• 26-year-old winger will join Slaven Bilic’s side on 1 July
• Feghouli: ‘The history of the club is very important for me in my decision’

The Algeria winger Sofian Feghouli has signed for West Ham United on a free transfer from Valencia. The 26-year-old winger will officially join the club on a three-year deal on 1 July.

Capped 40 times by his country, he will move to the Premier League following six seasons with Valencia.

Continue reading...

media:content.media:credit: Photograph: Arfa Griffiths/West Ham United via Getty Images
Photograph: Arfa Griffiths/West Ham United via Getty Images

item.dc:creator: Guardian sport

item.title: Manchester City interested in signing free-agent Víctor Valdés
item.description:
• Former Barcelona goalkeeper released by Manchester United
• Valdés could reunite with Pep Guardiola at Etihad Stadium

Manchester City’s search for a goalkeeper has led them to inquire about the availability of the former Manchester United and Barcelona player Víctor Valdés.

Valdés has been released by Manchester United having played only two first-team games after he was ostracised by the then United manager Louis van Gaal, who accused him of refusing to play in a reserve game. The former Barcelona No1 responded to Van Gaal’s criticism by posting a montage of photos on Twitter that showed a number of reserve-team matches he had played in.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Sid Lowe

item.title: Barcelona agree to pay £4.4m fine over Neymar tax fraud case
item.description:
• Barcelona accused of concealing part of Neymar transfer fee
• Brazilian joined Spanish club from Santos in 2013

Barcelona have agreed to pay a fine of €5.5m (£4.4m) to the Spanish authorities to settle a tax fraud case over the transfer of Neymar in 2013.

Barcelona had been accused of concealing part of Neymar’s transfer fee when he moved to Spain from the Brazilian club Santos, with several investigations carried out in Spain and Brazil.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: Jack Wilshere can accept losing midfield role to ‘perfect’ Wayne Rooney
item.description:
The England captain’s new position was a cause of debate before the Russia game but the Arsenal midfielder says Rooney proved his doubters wrong

It was a rueful smile that crossed Jack Wilshere’s face when the conversation turned to Wayne Rooney’s reinvention as an England international midfielder and the ramifications for the players who have built their entire careers around that position. “Yeah, cheers,” was Wilshere’s message for the England captain, in the manner of someone who had just taken a snowball to the face but recognised it was a damn good shot.

Wilshere, to be clear, was showing a neat line in humour once he had come down the long, gravelly path to Les Fontaines, the chateau in Chantilly where players make themselves available for interview. He blew out his cheeks in admiration when asked about Rooney’s performance against Russia and, if one thing came across from listening to the Arsenal player, it was the complete absence of any personal grievance.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Daniel Taylor in Chantilly

item.title: Russian officials blame security for problems and praise fighting fans
item.description:
• Reports of group travelling to Marseille to fight England fans dismissed
• ‘It’s true some Russian fans rushed English sector but it was nothing bad’

Russian officials have played down the violence over the weekend in Marseille – and in some cases even praised the fans involved. One top football official said the hooligans had defended the country’s honour and should be forgiven, while a top law enforcement official suggested Europe was “too gay” to know what real men look like.

Related: Moscow football official to violent fans: well done lads, keep it up!

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Shaun Walker in Moscow

item.title: Liverpool confirm João Teixeira has agreed a return to Portugal with Porto
item.description:
• Midfielder returning home after failing to make impact at Anfield
• Liverpool to receive about €300,000 compensation for 23-year-old

Liverpool have confirmed João Teixeira is to leave the club this summer having agreed a return to Portugal with Porto.

Related: Former Liverpool and Norway defender John Arne Riise announces retirement

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Andy Hunter

item.title: Mexico’s unbeaten streak shows they are serious Copa América contenders
item.description:
El Tri are coming into the form of their lives as the likes of Brazil crash out of the tournament. But how will they deal with losing their underdog status?

When Jesús “Tecatito” Corona darted past five defenders before firing in an outrageous 80th minute equaliser against in-form Venezuela on Monday evening it meant more to Mexico than just securing top spot of Group C in the Copa America. With that 1-1 draw at Houston’s packed NRG Stadium, Mexico extended their unbeaten run to 22 games, one better than their previous record, and made it a near certainty that they will avoid Argentina in Saturday’s quarter-final.

Related: Copa América: Mexico through as group winners after draw with Venezuela

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Duncan Tucker in Hermosillo

item.title: Miralem Pjanic completes €32m transfer to Juventus from Roma
item.description:
• Midfielder signs five-year contract with Serie A champions
• Bosnia-Herzegovina international had been linked with move to Chelsea

Juventus have completed the signing of Miralem Pjanic for £25.4m (€32m) from Roma on a five-year contract.

Related: Chelsea to step up attempts to sign Álvaro Morata from Juventus

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian sport and agencies

item.title: Aymeric Laporte, a Manchester City target, to stay with Athletic Bilbao
item.description:
• French defender signs new four-year deal with La Liga club
• City newcomer Ilkay Gundogan hopes to be fit by end of Ausust

The Manchester City target Aymeric Laporte has signed a new contract with Athletic Bilbao which will tie him to the club until the summer of 2020. The 22-year-old Frenchman had been strongly linked with City but a statement from Athletic on Monday evening said he was staying with the La Liga club.

They added that the release clause would for the defender would be €65m (£52m) for the 2016-17 and 2017-18 seasons, increasing to €70m for the two after that.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Press Association

item.title: Brazil's problems are far deeper than an early exit at Copa América
item.description:
Dunga’s team are out after an awful refereeing decision. But they have failed to recover from that infamous defeat to Germany - and may not make the next World Cup

Forget about the searing injustice. Try, if you can, to eradicate the memory of one of the worst refereeing displays ever seen in a major tournament.

Yes, the hapless Uruguayan referee, Andres Cunha, dropped an almighty blunder by allowing Raúl Ruidíaz’s winning goal for Peru on Sunday night despite a clear handball. This result – and the repercussions which will be long, arduous and potentially leave people searching for new jobs following Brazil’s shock exit from the Copa América Centenario – was, however, about more than just a bad call.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Steve Brenner

item.title: Ipswich Town owner being sued by Uefa over unauthorised Euro 2016 packages
item.description:
• Marcus Evans made his fortune in sports hospitality
• Uefa is suing unauthorised Euro 2016 ticket sellers

Hospitality companies belonging to Ipswich Town’s owner, Marcus Evans, are among those being sued by Uefa for allegedly selling unauthorised packages of Euro 2016 tickets.

As at every major sporting event a game of cat and mouse has been playing out in France between those offering unauthorised packages and the official hospitality provided by Uefa and its partners.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Owen Gibson

item.title: Championship club Reading appoint Jaap Stam as new manager
item.description:
• Former Manchester United defender handed first senior manager’s job
• Stam agrees initial two-year contract at Madejski Stadium

Reading have appointed the former Manchester United and PSV Eindhoven defender Jaap Stam as the club’s new manager. The 43-year-old has agreed an initial two-year contract at the Madejski Stadium. The Championship club sacked Brian McDermott at the end of the season following a disappointing campaign, in which they finished 17th.

The job will be Stam’s first in charge of a senior team, after spells as assistant and reserve-team manager at Ajax over the last three years. The Dutchman also becomes Reading’s first non-British manager.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Ben Fisher

item.title: Football transfer rumours: Chelsea and Barcelona battle for Samuel Umtiti?
item.description:
Today’s rumours are making the best of things

The Mill just cannot work in these conditions. First we hear that West Ham United have told Chelsea that Dimitri Payet is not for sale at any price and then we hear that Lyon have told West Ham United that Alexandre Lacazette is not for sale at any any price after the east London club made a renewed bid of £32m. And all that after Romelu Lukaku effectively pledged his allegiance to Everton by turning in a performance against Italy that ensures no one will be buying him this summer.

Much more of this and the Mill be reduced to making up deals. Oh, by the way, Paris Saint-Germain are looking for a top manager to take them to the next level, so are hoping to open talks with Roy Hodgson or Marc Wilmots after the Euros. Gah, saw through that one, didn’t you? In fact, PSG have reportedly already begun nattering to Unai Emery.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Paul Doyle

Today’s quiz is a permanent reminder of a temporary feeling

item.dc:creator: Steven Bloor

item.title: The Fiver | Needle doesn’t even nearly cover it
item.description:
In today’s Fiver: salted herrings, trouser touch-ups, and pod fan fiction

Before Tuesday’s game between Iceland and Portugal, great sages have been asking just what has made one small rock outcrop in the middle of two oceans capable of producing footballers of such ability that they can regularly humiliate the best bred by some of the world’s most populous and prestigious nations. With 103,001 square kilometres of land on which to hone their skills, Iceland is 128.6 times larger than Madeira, birthplace of Him. But how many Icelanders have won Big Cup? Where are their Ballons d’Or? Which of their players has been the subject of critically derided documentaries and been compelled to set up his own museum to his own self? The shameful answers are none, nowhere, nobody. They have never even appeared in a European Championship before. The list of Iceland’s achievements in the world of football is a list that nobody has ever needed to write.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Simon Burnton

item.title: Germany and Croatia state their intentions - Euro 2016 Football Daily
item.description:
The podders assess the impressive first outings for Croatia and Germany. Plus, Poland outclass Northern Ireland, and a lookahead to all tomorrow’s action

On today’s Football Daily, AC Jimbo and James Horncastle are joined by Michael Butler to look back on day 3 at the Euros, which saw Germany and Croatia put on strong showings against Ukraine and Turkey respectively. Zut alors!

It wasn’t quite such a welcome return to the big time for Northern Ireland however as they failed to muster a single shot as they went down 1-0 to Poland. Iain Macintosh was there and gives us his thoughts.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Presented by James Richardson and produced by Ben Green; with James Horncastle, Michael Butler, Sid Lowe and Iain Macintosh

item.title: The gifs that keep on giving: nutmegs, backflips, high kicks and a handshake
item.description:
Featuring the genius of Ronaldinho, LeBron James on the attack, a perfect pitch, two dancers on the sidelines and a goalkeeper saving face only to lose it

item.title: Djokovic's donkey cheese, curling controversy, and 'the Greatest' - Andy Zaltzman's Summer of Sport
item.description:
In the first of our new comedy-and-sport-but-definitely-non-football podcast series, Andy Zaltzman is joined by Mark Steel and Emma John to talk tennis, cricket, boxing and, er, curling

Welcome to Andy Zaltzman’s Summer of Sport - the brand new comedy and sport podcast series covering everything apart from that football thing in France. There’s Football Daily for that …

For this first outing Andy is joined by comedian Mark Steel and the Observer’s Emma John to discuss Novak Djokovic’s victory in the French Open and his continued dominance over Andy Murray (and everyone else, to be fair). It must be all the donkey cheese.

Continue reading...

item.title: You are the Umpire: Joe Root
item.description:
Click to enlarge, and debate the strip below the line.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Muhammad Ali: career KOs, Candid Camera and his recipe for life | Classic YouTube
item.description:
This week’s roundup also features European Championship memories, Robin Haase, drag racing and a PA gaffe in the Copa América

1) Where else to start but the great Muhammad Ali? His mesmerising speed, wit and sheer, undoubted talent inside the ring all went some way to constructing, as he said himself, the “perfect specimen of a man”. Ali, who died at the age of 74 last Friday, was superb value outside the ring too. Here he talks with Howard Cosell, and in 1971, he memorably sat down with Michael Parkinson, asking: “Why is Jesus white?” Here he is on Candid Camera in 1974, pranking some kids. Across the world, people – from Barack Obama to David Beckham – have been paying their respects and tributes to ‘the Greatest’. Documentary-wise, here is his life story, rare footage from ABC’s Wide World of Sports, and the Thrilla in Manila from HBO. Perhaps the most apt place to finish, though, is with Ali’s recipe for life, including two cups of love, one tablespoon of patience and one pint of kindness.

Related: Muhammad Ali – 25 of the best photographs of the legendary boxer

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian sport

item.title: Chris Scott’s costly drop: ‘You want to ask me about Brian Lara?’ | The Spin
item.description:
There has never been a drop in cricket that cost more than Chris Scott’s, off Brian Lara at Edgbaston on 3 June 1994

Ten seconds into our conversation, Chris Scott already knows where I’m heading. I’ve never met Scott or ever spoken to him. And for all the time I misspent studying scorecards on Ceefax in the 1990s, I struggle to recall anything much about his career. Scott was a wicketkeeper. He spent a decade understudying Bruce French at Nottinghamshire. Then he joined Durham in 1992, where he was “perhaps least celebrated”, as Stephen Brenkley wrote, “of the seasoned pros signed to ease Durham’s passage in their first years in the Championship”. Twenty‑four years later, Scott is on the other end of my phone.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Andy Bull

item.title: What is the shortest gap between a club debut and international cap? | The Knowledge
item.description:
Plus: most England caps when bypassing Wembley, 3.15pm kick-offs and Emlyn Hughes naming his children Emlyn and Emma Lynn. Mail your questions to knowledge@theguardian.com or tweet @TheKnowledge_GU

Marcus Rashford made his debut for the Manchester United senior team on 25 February in the Europa League and made his debut for England on 27 May. Is this the shortest gap between a senior debut and an international debut?” wonders John McDougall.

His rise has been startlingly quick but, no, there are a couple of others to have enjoyed shorter gaps.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Alan Smith

item.title: Pepe | The Gallery
item.description:
This week’s winner is Gareth Griffiths, who wins a copy of Ronald Reng’s book Matchdays: the Hidden Story of the Bundesliga. Next week we’d like your takes on … Didier Deschamps. Send your efforts to gallery@theguardian.com by noon on Monday 13 June as a jpeg, complete with a caption. Anyone who forgets will have to recite all of the Guardian’s Euro 2016 player profiles, word for word, backwards

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: The Agenda: Greg Rutherford jumps to it while Tony Bellew has a Goodison goal
item.description:
England boys of ’96 take turn to tell their story; England’s women footballers aim for the top; and the rowers put their backs into it for Rio 2016

The buildup to the Rio Games continues with Greg Rutherford in action at the fifth round of the Diamond League in Rome on Thursday (Eurosport 2), 7pm. The long jumper, who won gold at the London Games and went on to take the European and world titles, also topped the Diamond League rankings in the event last year. The British athlete is in mighty form as he prepares for the summer Olympics, having broken the British indoor record, with a jump of 8.26m in New Mexico in February, and with his win at the Manchester GreatCity Games last week he took his fifth victory this year in an unbeaten run that stretches back to July 2015. His confidence is, rightly, high.

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Giles Richards

item.title: Euro 2016 picture of the day – Northern Ireland pay their respects to Darren Rodgers
item.description:
Northern Ireland fans pay their respects to fan Darren Rodgers, the 24-year-old from Ballymena who died in Nice following his country’s fixture with Poland on Sunday evening after falling over a barrier and through the roof of a restaurant on the promenade of the French coast. Republic of Ireland supporters paid tribute to Rodgers during their draw with Sweden on Monday

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Daffydd Bynon

item.title: Minnows Iceland face Cristiano Ronaldo-led Portugal – video
item.description:
Iceland have qualified for their first ever international finals tournament. They came close in 2014, losing to Croatia in the World Cup play-offs, but managed to qualify directly after being drawn from Pot 5 – a feat matched by Northern Ireland and Albania. Their first ever European Championship game is against Cristiano Ronaldo’s Portugal, who have plenty to prove after a long line of disappointing tournament finishes

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Fisher and Ryan Baxter

item.title: Uefa confirms Russia's Euro 2016 suspended disqualification – video
item.description:
Uefa confirms on Tuesday that it has imposed a suspended disqualification on Russia in wake of violence by its supporters in Marseille. Europe’s football governing body says it has taken measures to avoid crowd trouble in Lille and Lens. Russia could be thrown out of Euro 2016 if their fans cause further trouble inside a stadium

  • Russia handed suspended Euro 2016 disqualification and lash out at England
Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Distraught father of jailed England fan calls sentencing a ‘disgrace’ – video
item.description:
The father of an England fan who was jailed and banned from France in connection with violence in Marseille says his son is being made a scapegoat. Speaking to media after the verdict, an emotional Chris Booth says injustice has been done to his 20-year-old son and vows to fight the sentence. Alexander Booth and Ian Hepworth were handed two and three- month sentences and banned from France for two years

  • Two England fans jailed in connection with Marseille violence at Euro 2016
Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Roy Hodgson and Wayne Rooney appeal to England fans to avoid violence – video
item.description:
Roy Hodgson and Wayne Rooney say they ‘desperately’ want to stay in the Euro 2016 tournament on Monday, and appeal to fans to avoid trouble after clashes followed England’s 1-1 draw with Russia on Saturday. In this footage posted to the official England Twitter page, Wayne Rooney asks fans without tickets for the next game not to travel

  • Russian hooligans behind Marseille violence were ‘trained to fight’
Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Rebekah Vardy: I feared for my life during Marseille violence – video
item.description:
Rebekah Vardy, wife of England striker Jamie, discusses the violence that erupted in Marseille following England’s 1-1 draw with Russia on Saturday. In an interview for ITV’s Good Morning Britain on Monday, Vardy says bags weren’t checked on the way into the stadium, which may have allowed Russian fans to gain entry with fireworks

  • Russian hooligans behind Marseille violence were ‘trained to fight’
Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Euro 2016 venue guides: Stade de Lyon, Lyon – video
item.description:
The Stade de Lyon will host six Euro 2016 games, including Italy’s opener against Belgium on Monday. Completed in January 2016, the stadium continues Lyon’s seemingly unstoppable rush to modernise, notably via the economic and architectural regeneration of La Confluence, at the southern end of its Presqu’ile district, Lyon remains a city dedicated to the French art of good living, be that in food or nightlife

  • Euro 2016: The complete guide to every team and player
Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Could Felix Verdejo be Puerto Rico's next boxing icon? – video
item.description:
The young lightweight sensation Felix Verdejo is poised to be the next big thing in the boxing world – and he hopes to ‘unite the Puerto Rican family’

Continue reading...

Photograph: Laurence Mathieu-Leger for the Guardian

item.dc:creator: Laurence Mathieu-Léger, Luis Miguel Echegaray

item.title: Eddie Jones: England can still improve after victory over Australia – video
item.description:
England coach Eddie Jones insists England can still ‘improve significantly’ despite a 39-28 victory over Australia in Brisbane on Saturday. Jones praises his Australian counterpart Michael Cheika as the ‘world’s best coach’, but says the pressure is on Australia to perform in the second Test

  • Southern comfort as England and Ireland turned rugby world on its head
Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Watch Muhammad Ali’s widow and daughter speak at packed memorial
item.description:
Muhammad Ali’s widow, Lonnie Ali, took the stage at her husband’s memorial to thunderous chants on Friday. In her first public remarks since his death, she talked about how Ali wanted to be remembered after his passing. ‘[Muhammad] wanted to use his life and his death as a teaching moment. He wanted to remind people who are suffering that he had seen the face of injustice,’ she said. Ali’s daughter, Rasheda Ali-Walsh, also spoke at the service

Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Why 24 is an awful number for a knockout tournament – Euro 2016 video
item.description:
Euro 2016 will be the largest iteration of the tournament to date, with 24 teams competing. But has Uefa tripped up? There’s an 87% chance of qualifying with three 0-0 draws. So rather than making a more exciting tournament, has Uefa encouraged caution? And with the best four third-placed teams qualifying for the round of 16, does that just add confusion?

  • Euro 2016 venues guide: all you need to know – video
Continue reading...
item.dc:creator: Anthony Richardson, Ryan Baxter Jonathan Fisher and Rachel Walker

item.title: Sport picture of the day: the high-flying Chiefs
item.description:
The Chiefs replacement Kayne Hammington flies though the air while making a pass as the Hamilton club overpowered and embarrassed the touring Welsh lineup with a historic 40-7 victory. It was the first time a Super Rugby side had defeated an international team and was Wales’s biggest provincial defeat by a New Zealand team

Continue reading...
